awd_titl_txt: Contact, Adhesion and Friction: From Atomic Interactions to Macroscopic Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Summary
Friction and adhesion affect almost all aspects of technology and everyday life. Despite their importance, our fundamental understanding of their origins and our ability to predict them in practical applications has remained limited. In large part, this is because of the wide range of length scales that are important. Adhesion and friction forces between surfaces result from interactions in regions where atoms are separated by less than a nanometer, but the geometry of these contact regions and the forces within them are determined by subsurface deformations on micrometer and longer scales. Over the last decade, advances in computational algorithms and hardware have begun to allow us to capture all of these length scales for the first time. The results have revealed qualitative shortcomings of traditional engineering models and resulted in simple equations that predict the area and stiffness of the contacts between rough surfaces. The proposed research will extend these studies to calculate friction and adhesive forces.  The goal is to provide new understanding of fundamental processes that will allow predictive models for the relation between surface roughness and macroscopic friction and adhesion to be developed. New computational tools will be developed and shared as open source software. 

Technical Summary
Contact, adhesion and friction are complex problems that involve a wide range of length scales. Atomic-scale interfacial interactions determine adhesive and frictional forces, but the area where these forces operate is determined by surface roughness and substrate deformation on nanometer to micrometer or longer scales. Traditional models of contact, adhesion and friction are based on macroscopic continuum equations with phenomenological constitutive relations for the interfacial interactions and macroscopic deformations. By their very nature, continuum equations do not include effects associated with discrete atoms, but most of the adhesive energy comes from changes in separation by a few angstroms and lateral frictional forces on a crystal are periodic with displacements by a lattice constant. The proposed research will address fundamental questions associated with the gaps between atomistic and continuum descriptions. These include the relation between atomic structure and detachment forces, the origins of friction and its connection to roughness, plasticity and disorder, and the extent of correlations in the dynamics at the interface. The goal is to provide new understanding of the physical processes at different scales and develop macroscopic models that incorporate atomic level processes.
Efficient multiscale methods that retain atomistic detail at the interface and capture the long-range response of the substrate will be extended, ported to open source simulation packages, and used to simulate contact and friction. The simulations will examine contact of planes and spheres with self-affine or experimentally measured surface roughness. The response of crystals, polymer glasses and elastomers will be studied in elastic and plastic limits with different atomic-scale roughness and adhesive interactions. Studies of contact and adhesion will determine how the contact area and detachment force are related to interfacial interactions, material properties and surface roughness. Studies of friction will address how interactions within these contacts lead to static and kinetic friction, how roughness and plasticity contribute to friction, and examine precursors to steady sliding where only part of the surface slips forward.

por.por_cntn:
Contact, adhesion and friction affect many aspects of everyday life and industry. Friction accounts for more than 20% of global energy consumption and improved understanding could affect 4% of the Gross Domestic Product.  Understanding friction is also of great intellectual interest because it requires modeling far from equilibrium systems on scales from nanometers to micrometers. The goal of the grant was to develop and apply methods that bridge this wide range of scales, calculating forces between atoms while including micrometer scale roughness.

Calculations of contact between dry rough surfaces have traditionally ignored correlations between neighboring contact points. The team participated in an international effort to identify the limits of such approximations. Consensus on best practices and the nature of contact when two nominally parallel surfaces have roughness on many scales was achieved.

An accurate Greens function approach was generalized to treat contact of dry, rough spheres. We calculated contact for spheres with a wide range of roughness, interfacial interactions and elastic properties. These results were then used to generate an analytic theory that predicts the variation of contact area for any rough sphere.

Contact between particles in fluid suspensions like oobleck or milk was also studied (Fig. 1). Previous theories assumed rigid, smooth particles. For a wide range of interactions we found that roughness and elasticity have little effect on the repulsion between surfaces, but reduce adhesion by orders of magnitude. This helps explain why particles pushed into contact can rapidly separate, allowing a fluid like ooblek to jam and then flow again.

When particles are only partially wet, like grains in a sand castle, they are pulled together by the surface tension of the liquid (Fig. 2). Molecular simulations were used to determine how these capillary forces vary at nanometer scales. Molecular structure leads to pronounced oscillations with separation and can change attraction into repulsion.

Models of friction traditionally assume that the friction coefficient or shear stress is independent of contact size. However new results for friction in nanometer scale contacts are very different than our every day experience. Indeed rigid, atomically flat surfaces have vanishing shear stress except in the very special case where surfaces have the same periodicity, as for identical aligned surfaces. This behavior has been called superlubricity, but is difficult to observe in macroscopic systems. Our Greens function method allowed us to study friction in contacts with radii from nanometer to micrometer scales. Small contacts act like rigid surfaces and display superlubricity unless they have a common period. Larger contacts can slide by independent motion of subregions, even if they are identical aligned crystals (Fig. 3). Perhaps most surprisingly, large contacts all slide at a shear stress that is independent of scale and nearly the same for identical, misaligned and disordered surfaces. There is no true superlubricity, but friction can be very weak when the substrate stiffness is much less than the local interfacial shear stress.

Surfaces are often lubricated to lower friction. Models of lubrication require the viscosity of the bulk fluid and interfacial boundary conditions. Most assume that the fluid velocity equals that of the solid at their interface. Simulations were used to calculate deviations from this no-slip boundary condition for curved and rough surfaces with different geometries. Atomistic effects lead to large variations in the degree of slip that can be predicted using the density modulations solids produce in the fluid and the lifetime of fluid vibrations.

Lubricants in bearings are typically under immense pressures and sheared at high rates. Simulations of real and model molecules revealed that two competing models for changes in the shear stress with rate are accurate in different regimes. In low viscosity fluids molecules are in nearly constant motion and the stress rises as a power of rate. In high viscosity fluids molecules move through rare thermally activated hops and stress rises as the logarithm of rate.

The low temperature flow of disordered systems like granular media, metallic glasses, earthquake gouge and wear debris in frictional contacts was also studied. Flow starts through a series of avalanches at a critical yield stress and rises as a power of rate. New scaling relations were derived connecting this power law to changes in correlation lengths and avalanche sizes and durations (Fig. 4).

Research was disseminated through talks and publications. The Greens function code was made publicly available and a website created that calculates contact properties for surfaces uploaded by users. The grant provided partial support for five graduate students and three have moved to national laboratories, universities and companies. Three undergraduate students, one female, worked with the group and are moving on to graduate school. Three high school students from under-represented groups did summer internships and are studying in STEM fields in college. Group members participated in multiple outreach efforts at Hopkins and classrooms in Baltimore City Schools.
